bestBHT.bht: The great harlot corrupts the earth with her fornication and is deserving of God's true and just judgments. These judgments serve as vengeance for the blood of his servants shed by her hand. This applies to both the Old Testament adulterous Church and the apostate New Testament Church, as well as those who mistreat messengers of truth. God ensures that his vengeance is exacted, demonstrating the righteousness of his judgments in the retribution he brings upon her.

Henry Alford: True and just are His judgments.
He judged the great harlot, which corrupted the earth in her fornication.
He exacted in vengeance the blood of His servants from her hand.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Instead of opposing and lessening, she promoted the sinful life and decay of the world by her own earthliness, allowing the salt to lose its savor.
A particular application of the principle.
Literally shed by the Old Testament adulterous Church, and by the New Testament apostate Church; also virtually, though not literally, by all who...show unkindness towards those who bear it.
Albert Barnes: For true and righteous are his judgments - That is, the calamities that come upon the power here referred to are deserved.
For he hath judged the great whore - The power represented by the harlot.
And hath avenged the blood of his servants - See the notes on Revelation 18:20, Revelation 18:24.
Philip Schaff: The word true of this verse again expresses what is real.
His judgments correspond to the reality and propriety of things.
The judgment particularly in view is specified in these words.
Archibald T. Robertson: He hath judged (εκρινεν). First aorist (prophetic and climacteric, effective) active indicative of κρινω."
This is the terrible fact. First aorist active indicative of φθειρω."
God has exacted vengeance for the blood of his servants from (εκ) her.
John Gill: For true and righteous are his judgments.
God's judgments on antichrist are intended.
And hath avenged the blood of his servants at her hand.
John Wesley: For true and righteous are his judgments — Thus is the cry of the souls under the altar changed into a song of praise.

bhtAttempts.bht: The verse speaks of God's true and just judgments against the great harlot, who corrupted the earth with her sinful ways and was responsible for the shed blood of his servants. The harlot promoted a sinful life and decay, causing the world to lose its spiritual freshness. This application extends to the Old Testament adulterous Church, the New Testament apostate Church, and all who show unkindness towards those who bear the message of truth. God has exacted vengeance for the blood of his servants from her, demonstrating the reality and propriety of his judgments.

The great harlot, who corrupted the earth with her fornication, is the target of God's true and just judgments. She promoted sin and decay, causing the loss of spiritual freshness, while shedding the blood of God's servants. This applies to the Old and New Testament churches, and those who mistreat messengers of truth. God's vengeance for the blood of his servants comes from her, vindicating his righteousness in his judgments.

The great harlot, whose corruption and fornication brought decay to the earth, faces God's true and just judgments. These judgments serve as a retribution for the blood of God's servants shed by her hand. This applies not only to the Old Testament adulterous Church and the New Testament apostate Church, but also to all who display unkindness towards those who bear the message of Truth. God ensures that his vengeance is exacted on her, demonstrating the retribution he rightfully deserves.

The great harlot, whose corruption and fornication led to the decay of the earth, greatly deserves God's true and just judgments. These judgments serve as retribution for the blood of his servants, which was shed by her hand. This applies not only to the unfaithful Old Testament Church, and the apostate New Testament Church, but also to those who mistreat those who carry the message of Truth. God ensures that his vengeance is meted out, affirming the righteousness of his judgments.

The great harlot corrupts the earth with her fornication and is deserving of God's true and just judgments. These judgments serve as vengeance for the blood of his servants shed by her hand. This applies to both the Old Testament adulterous Church and the apostate New Testament Church, as well as those who mistreat messengers of truth. God ensures that his vengeance is exacted, demonstrating the righteousness of his judgments in the retribution he brings upon her.
